titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Al Swift interview 2003 August 28
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rozlind Koester

publicationstmt.publisher: Western Washington University, Center for Pacific Northwest Studies

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid encoded by Rozlind Koester 2011
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS ( Describing Archives: A Content Standard).

did.abstract: The collection comprises an August 28, 2003 interview conducted by Midori Okazaki with Congressman Al Swift.

bioghist.p: Al Swift represented Washington State's second congressional district in the United States House of Representatives from 1978-1994.

scopecontent.p: The collection comprises an August 28, 2003 interview conducted by Midori Okazaki with Congressman Al Swift. Topics covered include Swift's appointment to the House Commerce Committee as a freshman congressman, his work with the House Administrative Committee, the Northwest Regional Power Act, the Motor Votor Bill, campain finance reform, timber resource management issues, the impact of the spotted owl controversy on rural communities, and the changing nature of Congress during his tenure. The recording is on VHS and DVC, with a full-text transcript available.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to the public.

userestrict.p: Please contact the Center for Pacific Northwest Studies in advance to arrange access to audio-visual equipment and recordings.

prefercite.p: Al Swift interview, Center for Pacific Northwest Studies, Western Libraries Archives & Special Collections, Western Washington University, Bellingham WA 98225-9123.

processinfo.head: About Harmful Language and Content
processinfo.p: To learn more about problematic content in our collections, collection description and teaching tools (including how to provide feedback or request dialogue on this topic), see the following Statement About Potentially Harmful Language and Content

acqinfo.p: Donated by Al Swift, date unknown.

separatedmaterial.p: Al Swift's Congressional Papers are also housed at the Center for Pacific Northwest Studies.

relatedmaterial.p: The Al Swift Congressional papers and the KVOS Channel 12 films (reflecting Swift's work as News Director during the 1960s) are also housed at the Center for Pacific Northwest Studies.
